questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of white discharge from her nipples for 4 months. During this period, menses have occurred at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals and have lasted 3 to 10 days; menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals with moderate flow. She has also had recurrent headaches that partially subside with ibuprofen. She has a healthy 5-year-old son. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Breast examination shows bilateral milklike discharge from the nipples; no masses are felt. Pelvic examination shows mild vaginal atrophy. An MRI of the head with contrast followed by hormone assays confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High levels of prolactin suppress the release of GnRH from the hypothalamus resulting in low levels of LH and FSH, and subsequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient likely has low estrogen levels, and estrogen replacement therapy (ERT) would improve her vaginal atrophy. However, ERT does not help to treat the underlying cause of her hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in asymptomatic patients with nonsecretory pituitary microadenomas. However, this patient has headaches, galactorrhea, irregular menses, and vaginal atrophy and should receive treatment. Without proper treatment, she is at risk of developing osteoporosis and infertility due to long-term suppression of sex hormone production. Also, further tumor growth may lead to bitemporal hemianopia or the destruction of normal pituitary gland tissue and deficiency of other pituitary hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the first-line treatment for most pituitary macroadenomas. Prolactinomas of any size, however, usually respond well to a less aggressive treatment modality; surgical resection is only considered as a second-line treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Dopamine receptor agonists such as cabergoline or bromocriptine are first-line treatments for all prolactinomas. By decreasing prolactin secretion they improve symptoms due to hyperprolactinemia such as galactorrhea, irregular menses, or vaginal atrophy, all of which are seen in this patient. Dopamine agonists usually also induce regression of tumor size, thereby improving symptoms due to mass effects such as headaches or bitemporal hemianopsia.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

External beam radiotherapy can be used to treat prolactinomas or other pituitary adenomas that do not respond to medical therapy or cannot be resected surgically. In this patient with likely prolactinoma, other treatment options should be tried first.
questions.hint: This patient's galactorrhea, irregular menses, vaginal atrophy, and confirmatory hormone assays indicate hyperprolactinemia. Her headaches and positive findings on MRI (likely an intrasellar mass) suggest a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (i.e., prolactinoma).

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not had her menses for 6 months. She has also had milky-white discharge from her nipples, frequent headaches, and blurry vision during the past 4 months. Menses had previously occurred at regular 30-day intervals and lasted for 4–5 days with moderate flow. She takes no medications. She has two children who are healthy and attend middle school. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (145 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy and a normal uterus. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient?



Prolactin
Follicle-stimulating hormone
Luteinizing hormone



A
Normal
decreased
decreased


B
Decreased
increased
increased


C
Increased
increased
increased


D
Decreased
decreased
decreased


E
Normal
increased
increased


F
Increased
decreased
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The constellation of normal prolactin level, decreased follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and decreased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be seen in a nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma because gonadotropic cells often respond to mass effect earlier than other cell types, e.g., those producing prolactin. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, visual changes), and this patient's amenorrhea and vaginal atrophy do suggest decreased FSH, resulting in low estrogen levels. However, her galactorrhea would suggest another hormonal abnormality.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and increased luteinizing hormone (LH) could be explained by a functioning gonadotroph adenoma, which may induce hypopituitarism via mass effect. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, which would explain this patient's sudden headaches and blurry vision. However, her estrogen level would be normal-to-high in the case of increased FSH secretion by the adenoma, which would not explain her vaginal atrophy — a sign of low estrogen levels. Also, her galactorrhea would indicate a different hormonal abnormality.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of elevated prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) might be seen if a functioning gonadotropic adenoma grew large enough to cause impingement of the infundibular stalk, leading to mild hyperprolactinemia secondary to the interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). Hyperprolactinemia can cause galactorrhea. However, elevated FSH leads to a normal/high estrogen and would not be consistent with vaginal atrophy, which is a sign of decreased estrogen.

D) INCORRECT:

The constellation of decreased prolactin, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) is seen in some forms of hypopituitarism, e.g., in a patient with a slow-growing, nonsecretory adenoma that compresses the regular hormone-secreting cells of the pituitary gland. A pituitary tumor could explain this patient's headaches and vision problems and decreased FSH could cause decreased estrogen levels, which would explain the vaginal atrophy and oligomenorrhea. However, her galactorrhea is highly suggestive of a different hormonal abnormality.

E) INCORRECT:

Normal prolactin, elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and elevated luteinizing hormone (LH) could be caused by a hormone-secreting gonadotropic adenoma. Although a pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms (e.g., headache, blurry vision), and increased FSH can cause amenorrhea (via ovarian hyperstimulation), the described constellation of hormones would not explain this patient's galactorrhea nor the vaginal atrophy.

F) CORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia has an inhibitory effect on GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone), which leads to a decrease in LH and FSH (luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone) and subsequently a decline in estrogen and testosterone, resulting in amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea, vaginal atrophy, and endometrial atrophy. Hyperprolactinemia has a direct tropic effect on breast tissue and triggers lactation, explaining this patient's galactorrhea — a finding that is seen in 80% of premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. A pituitary tumor of any kind can cause compressive symptoms, leading to bitemporal hemianopsia and/or palsy of the adjacent cranial nerves III, IV, or VI. The best next step in the diagnosis of suspected pituitary adenoma is a brain MRI with contrast. First-line treatment for prolactinomas is dopamine agonists (e.g., cabergoline), which inhibit prolactin secretion and induce shrinkage of the tumor.
questions.hint: The presence of amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and vaginal atrophy in a woman with new-onset headaches and blurry vision should raise suspicion of a prolactinoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches for 5 months. The headaches involve both temples and are 4/10 in intensity. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but the headaches did not subside. He has also had visual disturbances, including double vision. He has no nausea, temperature intolerance, or weight changes. The patient does not smoke. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure 125/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. An MRI scan of the head with contrast shows a 16 × 11 × 9 mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactorrhea is a very rare manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men but is commonly found in premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. Instead, gynecomastia is a common manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a somatotroph adenoma that can produce growth hormone. In adults, excess growth hormone can result in acromegaly, which typically manifests with coarse facial features. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of acromegaly, such as macrognathia, large hands and feet, and hypertension. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a thyrotroph adenoma that can produce thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can result in the development of a diffuse goiter and hyperthyroidism. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and heat intolerance. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, the most common form of which is a prolactinoma that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism because prolactin inhibits the synthesis and release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which results in decreased secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). In men, decreased concentrations of LH result in decreased production of testosterone in testicular Leydig cells. The resulting manifestations include erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, reduced testicular volume, infertility, gynecomastia, and loss of axillary hair. The visual deficits caused by a growing pituitary adenoma develop very gradually as the mass grows and compresses the optic chiasm (causing bitemporal hemianopia) and the oculomotor nerve (causing diplopia).

See “Clinical features of hyperprolactinemia” table.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a variant of which can produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and cause Cushing disease, which results in the development of abdominal striae. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Cushing disease, such as facial plethora, proximal muscle weakness, abnormal fat distribution, and easy bruising. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.
questions.hint: The intrasellar mass seen on this patient's MRI scan is likely a pituitary adenoma that is causing his headaches and bitemporal hemianopia. The most common form of pituitary adenomas is a prolactinoma. What are the potential consequences of this tumor in men?

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the gynecologist because of a 4-month history of irregular menstrual cycles. Menses occur at irregular 15 to 45-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. She also reports a milk-like discharge from her nipples for 3 months, accompanied by fatigue and muscle and joint pain. She does not have abdominal pain, fever, or headache. She has recently gained 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) of weight. She was diagnosed with schizophrenia and started on aripiprazole by a psychiatrist 8 months ago. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine for 6 months. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She appears healthy and anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy. Visual field and skin examination are normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.7 g/dL


Serum



Glucose
88 mg/dL


Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)
16.3 μU/mL


Cortisol (8 AM)
18 μg/dL


Prolactin
88 ng/mL


Urinalysis is normal. An x-ray of the chest and ultrasound of the pelvis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with thyrotropic pituitary adenomas have increased levels of TSH and clinical features of hyperthyroidism (secondary to increased TSH) such as weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea, and/or tachycardia. Large thyrotropic adenomas (> 10 mm) can present with features of hyperprolactinemia because they compress the infundibular stalk and result in an interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). However, since this patient is hypothyroid, thyrotropic pituitary adenoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ectopic prolactin production is a paraneoplastic syndrome that occurs in certain tumors such as lung and/or renal cell carcinoma. However, this patient does not have any clinical features suggesting malignancy. Also, ectopic prolactin production is extremely rare when compared with other forms of paraneoplastic hormone secretion (e.g., ectopic ACTH production).

C) INCORRECT:

Typical antipsychotics (and to a lesser extent, atypical antipsychotics) frequently cause hyperprolactinemia by blocking D2 dopamine receptors of the tuberoinfundibular region in the hypothalamus. However, aripiprazole is a unique atypical antipsychotic drug because it does not cause hyperprolactinemia. Aripiprazole acts as an agonist under hypodopaminergic conditions (thereby preventing hyperprolactinemia) but antagonizes D2 receptors under hyperdopaminergic conditions (thus retaining its antipsychotic effect).

D) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease could present with symptoms of hypercortisolism such as muscle pain and menstrual irregularities. However, the normal levels of early morning cortisol and the absence of hypertension and hyperglycemia make Cushing disease an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Increased TSH in a hypothyroid patient (e.g., fatigue, recent weight gain, and myalgia) who has not been taking their levothyroxine medication suggests primary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels stimulate the secretion of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) by the hypothalamus, which in turn increases TSH release by the anterior pituitary. In addition to increasing TSH production, excessive TRH also stimulates the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary to release prolactin, thus resulting in a state of hyperprolactinemia.

F) INCORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. However, prolactin levels in a patient with a prolactinoma are usually > 200 ng/mL. A prolactin level < 100 ng/mL in this patient suggests a different cause for hyperprolactinemia. Additionally, most secretory pituitary adenomas do not secrete multiple pituitary hormones, and prolactinomas that secrete TSH are extremely rare. Increased TSH levels suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Galactorrhea and irregular menstrual cycles are suggestive of hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of episodic headaches involving both temples for 5 months. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but it has not provided relief. He has also had double vision. Ophthalmic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. Contrast MRI of the head shows a 14 × 10 × 8-mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Macroglossia is a manifestation of acromegaly, which can be caused by growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. However, this tumor is uncommon. Another tumor with different findings is more likely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Impotence is common in men with hyperprolactinemia, which causes hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Prolactin inhibits the synthesis and release of GnRH, which results in low levels of FSH and LH secretion. Low levels of LH lead to low production of testosterone in testicular Leydig cells. In men, the lack of testosterone can cause erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, reduced testicular volume, impaired fertility, and loss of axillary hair. Pituitary macroadenomas may cause headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the surrounding structures (e.g., optic chiasm).

C) INCORRECT:

Galactorrhea occurs in hyperprolactinemia because prolactin stimulates milk production in the breasts. Hyperprolactinemia can be due to a prolactinoma or any sellar tumor that disrupts the inhibitory effect of the hypothalamus on the pituitary gland. Galactorrhea is commonly seen in premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. This finding is very rare in postmenopausal women and male patients with hyperprolactinemia. Another finding is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperpigmentation often manifests in Cushing disease, a form of secondary hypercortisolism that is caused by ACTH-producing pituitary adenomas. Other features include stretch marks (typically purple abdominal striae), hirsutism, and weight gain characterized by central obesity, moon facies, and dorsocervical fat pad, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, pituitary adenomas that produce ACTH are microadenomas, which usually do not cause mass effects (headache, bitemporal hemianopsia).

E) INCORRECT:

Diarrhea is a common manifestation of hyperthyroidism. Secondary hyperthyroidism is due to TSH-secreting adenomas, which are a very rare cause of sellar mass, accounting for < 5% of all functioning pituitary adenomas. While the mass effect of this kind of pituitary adenoma could explain this patient's headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia, the absence of other findings typical for excess TSH secretion (e.g., heat intolerance, weight loss, restlessness, or palpitation) makes a TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma very unlikely.
questions.hint: The intrasellar mass seen on this patient's MRI scan is likely a pituitary adenoma, which accounts for his headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia. The most common type of pituitary adenoma is a prolactinoma.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of irregular menses, milky discharge from her nipples, fatigue, and weight gain. Menses occur at irregular 25–40-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. 5 months ago, she was started on clozapine for treatment of schizophrenia. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine over the past 6 months. Visual field examination show no abnormalities. Her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone is 17.0 μU/mL and serum prolactin is 85 ng/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has hypothyroidism and does not take her medications, possibly as a result of schizophrenia. Increased TSH in a hypothyroid patient suggests primary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels stimulate the hypothalamus to release TRH (thyrotropin releasing hormone), which in turn increases TSH secretion by the anterior pituitary. In addition to increasing TSH production, excessive TRH also stimulates the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary to release prolactin, resulting in hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. However, prolactin levels in a patient with a prolactinoma are usually > 200 ng/mL. The fact that this patient's prolactin level is < 100 ng/mL makes a different cause for hyperprolactinemia more likely. Additionally, most secretory pituitary adenomas do not secrete multiple pituitary hormones, and prolactinomas that secrete TSH are extremely rare. This patient's increased TSH levels suggest another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with thyrotropic pituitary adenomas have increased levels of TSH and clinical features of hyperthyroidism (secondary to increased TSH) such as weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea, and/or tachycardia. Since this patient is hypothyroid, thyrotropic pituitary adenoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

Large thyrotropic adenomas (> 10 mm) can manifest with features of hyperprolactinemia because they compress the infundibular stalk and therefore interrupt the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). In addition, patients with large thyrotropic adenomas present with features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea), deficiencies of other pituitary hormones (secondary hypocortisolism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), and/or visual field defects.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic prolactin production is a paraneoplastic syndrome that occurs in certain tumors, e.g., lung or renal cell carcinoma. However, this patient does not have any clinical features suggesting malignancy. Moreover, ectopic prolactin production is extremely rare in comparison to other forms of paraneoplastic hormone secretion (e.g., ectopic ACTH production).

E) INCORRECT:

Typical antipsychotics, e.g., haloperidol, (and to a lesser extent, atypical antipsychotics such as risperidone) frequently cause hyperprolactinemia by blocking D2 dopamine receptors of the tuberoinfundibular region in the hypothalamus. However, although clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic, it does not commonly cause hyperprolactinemia.
questions.hint: Galactorrhea and irregular menstrual cycles suggest hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, decreased sexual desire, and difficulty achieving an erection. He has no past medical history except for a traumatic brain injury sustained in a motor vehicle accident 4 months ago. At that time, neuroimaging studies showed no abnormalities. Physical examination shows bilateral gynecomastia and a thin white nipple discharge. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms of erectile dysfunction, bilateral gynecomastia, galactorrhea, and loss of libido suggest hyperprolactinemia. Prolactin secretion by the anterior pituitary is under tonic inhibition by dopamine, which is secreted by hypothalamic neurons that project to the anterior pituitary via the tuberoinfundibular pathway. This patient's head trauma likely damaged the infundibular stalk, impairing dopamine transport to the anterior pituitary and reducing dopaminergic inhibition on pituitary lactotrophs (stalk effect). Prolactin stimulates lactation and can cause galactorrhea. Moreover, it suppresses gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which leads to decreased luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone. This lowers testosterone and causes symptoms of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, including loss of libido, erectile dysfunction, and bilateral gynecomastia.

B) INCORRECT:

Prolactin is likely to be increased rather than decreased in this patient. His symptoms of decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, bilateral gynecomastia, and galactorrhea suggest hyperprolactinemia.

Traumatic brain injury can also cause hypopituitarism and prolactin deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which manifests with a loss of libido, erectile dysfunction, and bilateral gynecomastia. However, decreased GnRH secretion alone would not explain his galactorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) stimulates prolactin secretion. Increased rather than decreased TRH leads to hyperprolactinemia. However, another underlying cause is more likely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Insufficient sex steroid production in the gonads leads to hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, which manifests with decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia, but galactorrhea is not expected.
questions.hint: This patient's head trauma likely caused damage to the infundibular stalk.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of headaches. He is at the 25th percentile for weight and 80th percentile for height. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. CT scan of the head shows a small suprasellar cystic mass compressing the infundibular stalk. Serum concentration of which of the following hormones is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The luteinizing hormone (LH) is produced by the gonadotropic cells of the anterior pituitary, under the influence of GnRH. Increased LH levels are typically seen with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and PCOS. A subclinical increase in LH levels also occurs in about a third of patients with gonadotropic pituitary adenomas, which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. In this patient, the levels of LH would be expected to be low due to the inhibition of GnRH secretion by the hormone that is increased in concentration.
Image Description:

The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

B) INCORRECT:

Somatotropin (growth hormone) is produced and released by the somatotropic cells of the anterior pituitary under the influence of GHRH, which reaches the pituitary gland via the hypophyseal portal system. The serum concentration of somatotropin can be increased in gigantism, which is most often caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. Moreover, children with gigantism typically present with tall stature and obesity; this child's height and weight percentiles are within normal limits. Compression of the pituitary stalk, as seen here, would typically result in a decrease in GH secretion as a result of interruption of the hypophyseal portal system.
Image Description:

Hypothalamic hormone GHRH (growth hormone-releasing hormone) stimulates the release of growth hormone (GH) from the acidophilic cells of the pituitary gland. GH-release is inhibited by somatostatin (growth hormone-inhibiting hormone, GHIH), which is produced in the hypothalamus and D cells (pancreas, duodenum). Ghrelin (produced in stomach) acts as another stimulator of GH-release.

As a nontropic hormone, GH either directly stimulates target cells or acts indirectly via synthesis of insulin-like growth factors (IGFs). GH-release is inhibited by GH itself and IGFs, GHRH-release only by IGFs.

C) CORRECT:

The infundibulum is the connection between the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland. Compression of this connection decreases the amount of dopamine delivery from the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary gland. Dopamine normally inhibits the secretion of prolactin by the lactotroph cells. The loss of inhibition on lactotroph cells results in increased secretion of prolactin hormone (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). Increased prolactin levels would also decrease the levels of gonadotrophins (e.g., LH, FSH) by inhibiting GnRH release.
Image Description:

The nontropic releasing hormones are released in the hypothalamus (A) to the portal vascular system of the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis , 2), where the nontropic hormones growth hormone (GH), melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and prolactin are released (2). These trigger the secretion of hormones in the target organs: GH leads to the secretion of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the liver, which has an anabolic effect on the muscles and bones (3). In the skin, MSH stimulates the production of melanocytes (4). Prolactin triggers growth and lactation in the mammary glands (5). The inhibiting hormones are also released in the hypothalamus and subsequently reach the anterior pituitary gland, where they inhibit the release of nontropic hormones.

(GHRH = growth hormone-releasing hormone, TRH = thyrotropin-releasing hormone, MSH-RH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-releasing hormone, MSH-IH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-inhibiting hormone, Dop = dopamine)

D) INCORRECT:

The adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is produced by the adrenocorticotropic cells of the anterior pituitary, under the influence of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which reaches the pituitary gland via the hypophyseal portal system. The levels of ACTH would be increased in patients with an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease), which can cause a headache. A pituitary adenoma would, however, arise within the sella turcica unlike the suprasellar mass in this patient. Moreover, children with Cushing disease typically present with features of secondary hypercortisolism such as central obesity, moon-like faces, proximal muscle atrophy, striae, and hyperpigmentation, which have not been reported in this patient. Compression of the pituitary stalk, as seen here, would typically result in a decrease in ACTH secretion as a result of interruption of the hypophyseal portal system.
Image Description:

The hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into the portal vessels of the pituitary stalk, through which they reach the anterior pituitary gland. These hypothalamic hormones then directly influence the release of tropic hormones from the anterior pituitary gland into the peripheral bloodstream. GnRH stimulates the release of both luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), CRH stimulates adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and TRH stimulates thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

LH and FSH act on the ovaries/testes to produce sex hormones (estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone); ACTH stimulates the adrenal gland to produce glucocorticoids (primarily cortisol); and TSH stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones (T3 and T4).

The hypothalamus also influences the release of nontropic hormones like prolactin and growth hormone (GH) from the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin regulates lactation in the mammary glands; GH is stimulated by growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) and in turn stimulates the production of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) in the liver.

Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops, where the hormones produced by target organs can inhibit the release of their controlling hormones from the hypothalamus and pituitary.

E) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and sent directly to the posterior pituitary gland via neurophysins for storage and release. Any compression of the pituitary stalk is likely to narrow this connection and result in a reduced amount of stored vasopressin in the posterior pituitary. This patient's suprasellar mass with compression of the pituitary stalk is more likely to result in a decreased amount of released vasopressin.
Image Description:

(1) Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are synthesized in the nuclei of the hypothalamus.
(2) Both hormones are transported to the posterior pituitary gland (neurohypophysis) via the hypothalamic nerve cell axons and released in the blood.
(3, 4) Oxytocin induces uterine contractions, ADH promotes water reabsorption in the collecting tubules of the kidney
questions.hint: This 8-year old patient with a history of headaches and a CT-scan finding of a suprasellar cystic mass is most likely presenting with a craniopharyngioma. Any suprasellar lesion, including craniopharyngiomas, can compress the pituitary (infundibular) stalk, which can impede communication between the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of headaches, irregular menses, and nipple discharge for the past 4 months. Breast examination shows milky white discharge from both nipples. Her thyroid function tests and morning cortisol concentrations are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely in this patient?



Serum estrogen
Serum progesterone
Dopamine synthesis



A
No change
no change
no change


B
↑
no change
no change


C
↓
↓
↓


D
↓
↓
↑


E
↑
↑
no change
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal levels of dopamine, estrogen, and progesterone suggest a physiologic state. In combination with the headaches and mass presenting in the pituitary area on MRI, however, this constellation would also be consistent with a small non-secretory pituitary adenoma. A small non-secretory pituitary adenoma would not present with galactorrhea, which, together with this patient's headaches and menstrual irregularities, makes a lactotrophic pituitary adenoma much more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

An isolated increase in estrogen could be caused by a granulosa cell tumor, a low-grade malignant ovarian tumor that produces estrogen (but may produce progesterone as well) and most commonly affects postmenopausal women. The increase in estrogen can lead to menstrual irregularities (postmenopausal bleeding) and breast tenderness, but not galactorrhea. Headaches and a mass in the area of the pituitary gland are not consistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Rarely, a large nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma that compresses the dopamine-producing hypothalamic neurons can result in this set of changes. A decreased synthesis of dopamine would suspend its tonic inhibition of prolactin release. Secretion of LH and FSH would consequently decrease because of either the increase in prolactin or the compression of gonadotroph cells by the adenoma. A decreased secretion of LH and FSH would lead to impaired production of progesterone and estrogen, resulting in a hypogonadal state. However, there is no evidence of hypothalamic compression on this patient's MRI. In addition, a tumor large enough to compress the hypothalamus would likely also impair the production of ACTH (resulting in hypocortisolism) and TSH (resulting in hypothyroidism), which are not affected in this patient. More commonly, large nonfunctioning pituitary adenoma can compress the pituitary stalk, resulting in mild hyperprolactinemia due to loss of feedback inhibition by dopamine; dopamine synthesis, however, would not be decreased.


D) CORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas are benign tumors that arise from the anterior pituitary gland and can produce hormones (secretory pituitary adenomas). Lactotrophic adenomas (prolactinomas) secrete prolactin, which can manifest with galactorrhea, as is the case here. Prolactin also stimulates the compensatory hypothalamic synthesis and secretion of its own inhibitory factor, dopamine, via a short-loop feedback mechanism. Moreover, prolactin inhibits GnRH secretion, thus causing a decrease in the release of FSH and LH. This leads to decreased serum estrogen and progesterone levels (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), which can manifest with menstrual irregularities and decreased libido.

The physiologic increase in dopamine (prolactin-inhibitory factor) is insufficient to counteract the excess release of prolactin from lactotroph adenomas. Dopamine agonists (e.g., cabergoline), which are the treatment of choice of prolactinomas, effectively decrease the release of prolactin from lactotroph cells and reduce the size of adenomas.
Image Description:

The nontropic releasing hormones are released in the hypothalamus (A) to the portal vascular system of the anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis , 2), where the nontropic hormones growth hormone (GH), melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and prolactin are released (2). These trigger the secretion of hormones in the target organs: GH leads to the secretion of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) in the liver, which has an anabolic effect on the muscles and bones (3). In the skin, MSH stimulates the production of melanocytes (4). Prolactin triggers growth and lactation in the mammary glands (5). The inhibiting hormones are also released in the hypothalamus and subsequently reach the anterior pituitary gland, where they inhibit the release of nontropic hormones.

(GHRH = growth hormone-releasing hormone, TRH = thyrotropin-releasing hormone, MSH-RH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-releasing hormone, MSH-IH = melanocyte-stimulating hormone-inhibiting hormone, Dop = dopamine)

E) INCORRECT:

An elevation in estrogen and progesterone but not in dopamine can be seen in the first trimester of intrauterine pregnancy (during the third trimester, dopamine would also increase). Since a negative urine pregnancy test does not rule out early pregnancy (elevated HCG can only be detected about 10 days after the first missed period), this diagnosis is possible. However, breast discharge would be unlikely in this very early stage and this patient's headache and mass on MRI are more consistent with lactotrophic pituitary adenoma.
questions.hint: This patient's galactorrhea, menstrual irregularities, headaches, and MRI findings (a mass located in the sella turcica) indicate an anterior pituitary lactotroph adenoma.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a primary concern of amenorrhea. She reports that she had regular and predictable periods every month until age 30 when they became quite irregular. Her last period was 6 months ago. She is otherwise asymptomatic and reports no headaches or vision changes.
Her medical history is notable for asthma, which has been controlled with a low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid since childhood, and schizophrenia, which is managed with risperidone. She has a family history of thyroid cancer and hypertension.
Her physical examination is notable for a BMI of 29.4, which has increased slightly since her last visit 12 months ago. There is no excess hair growth or acne. Gynecologic examination is normal, although examination of the breasts shows spontaneous galactorrhea.
A complete blood count and ferritin measurement performed last month are within normal limits. Further laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Serum human chorionic gonadotropin (mIU/mL)
<5
<5


Follicle-stimulating hormone (mIU/mL)
3

MenstruatingFollicular phase: 3–20Ovulatory phase: 9–26Luteal phase: 1–12Postmenopausal 18–153



Estradiol (pg/mL)
21

MenstruatingFollicular phase: <20–145Mid-cycle peak: 112–443Luteal phase: <20–241Postmenopausal <59



Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
4.2
0.5–4.7


Prolactin (ng/mL)
155
0–20


What is the most likely cause of this patient’s amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting with secondary amenorrhea, defined as the absence of menses for 3 months in those with previously regular cycles or for 6 months in those with irregular cycles. Amenorrhea can occur due to abnormalities in the pituitary gland, ovaries, or genital outflow tract (uterus and vagina). In a patient with previously normal periods, pituitary and ovarian causes should be suspected.

The first step in patients with secondary amenorrhea is to rule out pregnancy. In those who are not pregnant, a further assessment is indicated; in this case, that evaluation revealed a significantly elevated level of prolactin, which is secreted by the pituitary gland during pregnancy, lactation, nipple stimulation, and stress.

Elevated prolactin levels lead to amenorrhea through disruption of the normal cyclical release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone. Prolactin release is tonically suppressed by dopamine release from the hypothalamus, so any situation that reduces dopamine action on the pituitary gland can lead to a rise in the serum prolactin level. This includes any medication that has dopamine antagonist properties.

The most common medications to cause hyperprolactinemia are the typical and atypical antipsychotics. In this case, the patient is taking the atypical antipsychotic risperidone, which is therefore the most likely cause of her hyperprolactinemia with resulting amenorrhea. Gastric motility drugs, such as metoclopramide and domperidone, and selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors are other medications that can raise prolactin levels.

Key learning point: Antipsychotics and other medications with dopamine antagonistic properties can cause clinically significant elevations in prolactin levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperandrogenism can cause secondary amenorrhea; however, there was no indication of this on the patient’s physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids are not known to cause prolactin release.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency can cause secondary amenorrhea; however, given loss of negative feedback from ovarian estradiol production, the levels of follicle-stimulating hormone would be expected to be elevated.

E) INCORRECT:

Mass lesions that disrupt the pituitary stalk, through which dopamine is transported, and prolactin-releasing pituitary adenomas (prolactinomas) can also cause elevated prolactin levels. In this patient, however, another cause is a more likely culprit than a prolactinoma.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents with bilateral nipple discharge and oligomenorrhea for the past year. She describes her cycles as irregular, usually occurring every 6 to 10 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Menarche was at 12 years of age with regular cycles until this past year. The patient takes no medications and has never been pregnant. She is not sexually active and has never tried to conceive. She reports no changes in vision, including double vision or loss of vision, and no headaches, hirsutism, or acne.
On physical examination, she has a BMI of 32, a blood pressure of 128/71 mm Hg, a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, and a temperature of 36.2°C. Her breasts are symmetric with normal appearance. Application of pressure around the areola causes bilateral nipple discharge of a white, milky-appearing fluid without evidence of blood. The remainder of the physical examination, including extraocular movements and confrontation testing for visual fields, is normal.
Laboratory testing reveals a prolactin level of 162 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20) and an insulin-like growth factor-1 level of 120 ng/mL (114–492). Renal function is normal.
A repeat fasting prolactin level remains elevated at 147 ng/mL. The thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.4 μU/mL (0.5–4.7), and the free thyroxine level is 1.2 ng/dL (0.8–1.8). A urine pregnancy test is negative.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who have functioning pituitary tumors other than prolactinomas and those with symptoms of nonfunctioning macroadenomas (impaired vision, headaches, and/or hypopituitarism) should be referred to neurosurgery for surgical removal. Prolactinomas can be managed medically with dopamine agonists in the vast majority of cases and do not require neurosurgery referral unless medical therapy is ineffective.

B) INCORRECT:

Medical treatment is the preferred initial management for prolactinomas of any size. Dopamine agonists (including cabergoline) can reduce both the size of the adenoma and the secretion of prolactin from it. However, treatment should be initiated only after a pituitary MRI has ruled out alternate causes of the hyperprolactinemia.

C) INCORRECT:

A progestin-withdrawal test can be included in the evaluation of unexplained secondary amenorrhea; withdrawal bleeding would indicate an intact outflow tract and the presence of estrogen. However, this patient’s amenorrhea is not unexplained: hyperprolactinemia is present, and a progestin-withdrawal test is therefore not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with pituitary adenomas affecting the optic chiasm on imaging should have formal visual-field testing. However, MRI should be the initial testing modality.

E) CORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia may be physiologic (as in pregnancy) or pathophysiologic. Pathophysiologic causes include the presence of a prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenoma (prolactinoma), tumors of the hypothalamus (craniopharyngioma), disease processes affecting the hypothalamic-pituitary connection (infundibulum), certain medications (e.g., antipsychotics, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors), hypothyroidism, and chronic renal failure.

The first step in the evaluation of a patient with persistent hyperprolactinemia without a clear etiology is contrast-enhanced MRI of the pituitary gland to evaluate for masses in the hypothalamic-pituitary region.

Key learning point: The first step in the diagnostic evaluation of a patient with unexplained persistent hyperprolactinemia is to order a pituitary MRI.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman describes intermittent milky discharge from both breasts for the past 6 months. She also states that her menstrual cycle has become irregular during this time, with only two menses since the nipple discharge started. She is sexually active and reports reduced libido. She is hoping to conceive in the future and is concerned about her irregular menses. She does not take any medications and is otherwise healthy. She reports no changes in vision and has only occasional headaches, which she describes as chronic and stress related.
On physical examination, she has bilateral milky discharge with minimal areolar pressure and no discernible breast mass. Bilateral temporal visual-field defects are noted on visual-field examination.
Laboratory testing shows a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 2.4 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), a free thyroxine level of 1.4 ng/dL (0.8–1.8), and a prolactin level of 389 ng/mL (0–20). A urine pregnancy test is negative.
A repeat fasting prolactin level remains elevated. Renal function is normal.
MRI of the sella demonstrates an 18-mm sellar mass with suprasellar extension and compression of the optic chiasm, most consistent with a pituitary adenoma.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Begin an oral contraceptive containing estrogen and progesterone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the tumor is resistant to medical management, surgery may be necessary as second-line treatment, but this is relatively infrequent. Most patients who are considered resistant to dopamine agonist therapy have a partial response, meaning there is tumor shrinkage and the prolactin level decreases but does not normalize. In these cases, endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery may be necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

An oral contraceptive would not treat the underlying cause of this patient’s oligomenorrhea and would further impair her ability to conceive.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. Prolactinomas may manifest with galactorrhea, oligomenorrhea, or amenorrhea; decreased libido; erectile dysfunction; infertility; and osteopenia. Depending on the size of the prolactinoma, other symptoms may include headaches, visual-field disturbances, cranial-nerve palsies, symptoms of hypopituitarism, and, in rare cases, seizures or hydrocephalus. All patients with hyperprolactinemia of unclear etiology should undergo MRI to evaluate for a prolactinoma.

First-line treatment of prolactinoma is dopamine agonist therapy. Bromocriptine and cabergoline are both effective at quickly reducing the prolactin level and shrinking the tumor over time. Both medications are options in patients who are trying to achieve pregnancy, but the safest approach in the setting of optic-chiasm compression may be to defer pregnancy until the tumor has shrunk, to avoid progression of vision symptoms under the influence of the elevated estrogen levels that occur during pregnancy. Uncontrolled primary hypothyroidism can lead to hyperprolactinemia.

Key learning point: The initial management for a patient with hyperprolactinemia and evidence of a pituitary adenoma with optic-chiasm compression on sellar MRI is dopamine agonist therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Stereotactic radiotherapy can reduce the size of a prolactinoma, but it can take years to achieve maximal effect, and hypopituitarism can occur. Radiotherapy is therefore reserved for rare cases of prolactinomas that cannot be managed medically or surgically.

E) INCORRECT:

If hypothyroidism is present, it should be corrected before treatment of hyperprolactinemia is initiated. In this case, the patient’s thyroid function was found to be normal, so treatment with levothyroxine would not be appropriate.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a 9-mm pituitary adenoma that was detected incidentally during a brain MRI for persistent left-sided migraine headaches. A follow-up pituitary-protocol MRI showed that the lesion is entirely in the sella without suprasellar extension, and there is no pituitary stalk involvement.
The patient has had no visual symptoms and no signs or symptoms of hypercortisolism. She reports that she experienced menopause at age 51 and has had no vaginal bleeding, hot flashes, breast tenderness, or milky breast discharge. She takes no medications or supplements.
Her fasting serum prolactin level is 107 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20) and, on repeat measurement, is 102 ng/mL. Her serum estradiol level is 21 pg/mL (reference range for postmenopausal women, <59). Her thyroid-stimulating hormone, free thyroxine, and insulin-like growth factor-1 levels are all normal. A 1-mg dexamethasone suppression test shows a fully suppressed cortisol level after administration of dexamethasone. Renal function is normal.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Begin oral estradiol 2 mg daily, along with micronized progesterone 100 mg daily
Begin cabergoline 0.25 mg twice weekly; remeasure the prolactin level in 3 months
Refer the patient for surgical resection of the tumor
Reassure the patient that no immediate treatment is indicated; consider another MRI in 1 to 2 years
Begin bromocriptine 2.5 mg daily; remeasure the prolactin level in 1 month

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Replacement of estrogen (and progesterone in women with an intact uterus) may be recommended in a premenopausal woman with a prolactinoma who cannot tolerate dopamine-agonist therapy, but it would not be routinely prescribed for a postmenopausal woman.

B) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy with a dopamine agonist, such as cabergoline or bromocriptine, would be reasonable in a postmenopausal woman with a larger prolactinoma or if there was evidence of impaired pituitary function or vision symptoms related to mass effect. However, in postmenopausal women, medical therapy is not always needed. For smaller pituitary tumors (<1 cm; as in this case), observation is a reasonable option, with monitoring of prolactin levels and follow-up imaging considered every 1 to 2 years if the tumor is between 5 mm and 9 mm or if the prolactin level rises significantly (to >200 ng/mL).

C) INCORRECT:

Surgery is never first-line therapy for patients with a prolactinoma and is therefore not recommended.

D) CORRECT:

Prolactin-secreting tumors are the most common form of hormone-secreting pituitary tumor. In premenopausal women, these tumors may be associated with irregular or absent menses, breast tenderness, and galactorrhea, all due to elevated prolactin levels and associated reductions in luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone. In postmenopausal women, who already have amenorrhea and low estradiol levels, prolactinomas are often asymptomatic. Regardless of a patient’s menopausal status, larger tumors (especially those measuring ≥1 cm) and tumors with suprasellar extension may be associated with additional signs and symptoms related to mass effect — including vision changes, headaches, and pituitary hormonal deficiencies.

Most premenopausal women with prolactinomas should be treated with medical therapy with a dopamine agonist to lower prolactin levels, diminish galactorrhea, restore normal menstrual cycles and estrogen levels, improve fertility, and shrink the tumor when necessary.

However, in postmenopausal women, medical therapy is not always needed. For smaller pituitary tumors (<1 cm; as in this case), observation is a reasonable option, with monitoring of prolactin levels and follow-up imaging considered every 1 to 2 years if the tumor is between 5 mm and 9 mm or if the prolactin level rises significantly (to >200 ng/mL).

Medical therapy with a dopamine agonist, such as cabergoline or bromocriptine, would be reasonable in a postmenopausal woman with a larger prolactinoma or if there was evidence of impaired pituitary function or vision symptoms related to mass effect.

Key learning point: In a postmenopausal woman with a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma <1 cm in size, the most appropriate management is observation without immediate medical or surgical therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Medical therapy with a dopamine agonist, such as cabergoline or bromocriptine, would be reasonable in a postmenopausal woman with a larger prolactinoma or if there was evidence of impaired pituitary function or vision symptoms related to mass effect. However, in postmenopausal women, medical therapy is not always needed. For smaller pituitary tumors (<1 cm; as in this case), observation is a reasonable option, with monitoring of prolactin levels and follow-up imaging considered every 1 to 2 years if the tumor is between 5 mm and 9 mm or if the prolactin level rises significantly (to >200 ng/mL).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents with bilateral nipple discharge for the past week. The patient reports that the discharge looks milky and only occurs when pressure is applied to her breasts. Her mother was recently diagnosed with breast cancer at age 50, and the patient is very worried that she might also have the condition.
The patient is often tired and has occasional headaches, which she attributes to school stress and lack of sleep. She reports no pain, redness, or itching of the breast, fever, visual changes, nausea, abdominal pain, or problems with bowel or bladder function. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and has been taking a combined oral contraceptive pill for pregnancy prevention for the past 6 months. Menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days, and she has not missed any periods. One year ago, she was diagnosed with obsessive-compulsive disorder and started on fluoxetine, which she feels has helped immensely. The patient occasionally drinks alcohol and smokes marijuana once per month but reports no tobacco or other drug use.
Vital signs are within normal limits. A few drops of milky discharge can be expressed from multiple ducts of both breasts. There are no visible or palpable breast abnormalities and no axillary lymphadenopathy. Ophthalmologic and neurologic examinations are normal. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and thyroid-stimulating hormone level are normal. Prolactin is measured at 50 ng/mL (reference range, 0–30). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary
Measure follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone levels
Switch the fluoxetine to sertraline, and then recheck prolactin
Switch the oral contraceptive to a progesterone-only contraceptive, and then recheck prolactin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality for detecting breast abnormalities in patients <30 years of age. Although ultrasound is used in the workup of unilateral and/or bloody nipple discharge to evaluate for pathologies of the breast, it is not indicated in patients with bilateral, non-bloody nipple discharge (i.e., galactorrhea), which typically has a systemic cause.

B) CORRECT:

Bilateral, multiductal, milky nipple discharge in non-lactating individuals is called galactorrhea. Galactorrhea can be due to excessive manual stimulation of the breasts, medication effects, prolactinoma, other pituitary or hypothalamic lesions, hypothyroidism, or kidney or liver failure. This condition is usually associated with elevated prolactin levels, which inhibit GnRH secretion, leading to decreased FSH and LH. This can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, resulting in amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, and/or sexual dysfunction. This patient’s periods may have remained regular due to the effects of her combined oral contraceptive pill.

Pregnancy should be ruled out in premenopausal patients with galactorrhea after history is obtained and a clinical examination is performed. Laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the next diagnostic step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia. Non-pregnant patients with hyperprolactinemia should undergo further laboratory workup including serum TSH levels, creatinine, and liver function testing to assess for hypothyroidism and other secondary causes of prolactinemia. Ophthalmologic testing should be performed to assess for signs of compression of the optic chiasm due to pituitary or hypothalamic tumors. If a medication is strongly suspected as the underlying cause, it should be stopped or changed, and prolactin levels should be remeasured. A pituitary MRI with contrast should be performed to rule out pituitary and hypothalamic lesions when hyperprolactinemia is not clearly attributable to another cause.

Key learning point: In a female adolescent with galactorrhea and hyperprolactinemia that is not clearly attributable to a medication, the workup should include: a pregnancy test, TSH, and magnetic resonance imaging of the pituitary.

C) INCORRECT:

Sex hormones, including estrogen, testosterone, FSH, and LH, should be measured in patients with signs of hypogonadism, which this patient does not have. Moreover, her FSH and LH levels are likely suppressed because she is taking combined oral contraceptive pills.

D) INCORRECT:

If a medication is strongly suspected to be the underlying cause of nipple discharge, it should be discontinued or changed to a medication with a lower likelihood of increasing prolactin levels before these levels are remeasured. Although selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) use has in rare cases been associated with galactorrhea, this patient has been taking fluoxetine for a year without symptoms, making it an unlikely cause. Furthermore, since any SSRI may have this effect, switching from one to another is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms.

Medications associated with hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea include antipsychotics, antiemetics, and antihypertensives (in particular methyldopa).

E) INCORRECT:

If a medication is strongly suspected to be the underlying cause of nipple discharge, it should be discontinued or changed, and prolactin levels should be remeasured. Although increased levels of estrogen are associated with hyperprolactinemia, the amount of estrogen found in combined oral contraceptives is low and unlikely to have this effect. Furthermore, this patient has been taking an oral contraceptive for six months without symptoms, making it an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of episodic headaches for 5 months. The headaches involve both temples and are 4/10 in intensity. The patient has been taking acetaminophen, but the headaches did not subside. He has also had visual disturbances, including double vision. He has no nausea, temperature intolerance, or weight changes. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure 125/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows impaired peripheral vision bilaterally. An MRI scan of the head with contrast shows a 16 × 11 × 9 mm intrasellar mass. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactorrhea is a very rare manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men but is commonly found in premenopausal women with hyperprolactinemia. Instead, gynecomastia is a common manifestation of hyperprolactinemia in men.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a somatotroph adenoma that can produce growth hormone. In adults, excess growth hormone can result in acromegaly, which typically manifests with coarse facial features. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of acromegaly, such as macrognathia, large hands and feet, and hypertension. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a rare variant of which is a thyrotroph adenoma that can produce thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can result in the development of a diffuse goiter and hyperthyroidism. However, this patient does not have typical manifestations of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and heat intolerance. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, the most common form of which is a prolactinoma that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia results in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism because prolactin inhibits the synthesis and release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), which results in decreased secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). In men, decreased concentrations of LH result in decreased production of testosterone in testicular Leydig cells. The resulting manifestations include erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, reduced testicular volume, infertility, gynecomastia, and loss of axillary hair. The visual deficits caused by a growing pituitary adenoma develop very gradually as the mass grows and compresses that optic chiasm (causing bitemporal hemianopia) and the oculomotor nerve (causing diplopia).

See “Clinical features of hyperprolactinemia” table.
Image Description:

MRI head (T1-weighted; without contrast; sagittal plane) of a male patient with headache, retroorbital pressure, fatigue, and elevated serum prolactin

A large mass, which is isointense to gray matter, is seen in the area of the sella turcica (indicated by arrows).

Considering the patient's history, a prolactin-secreting macroadenoma (prolactinoma) of the pituitary gland is the most likely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has a pituitary adenoma, a variant of which can produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and cause Cushing disease, which results in the development of abdominal striae. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of Cushing disease, such as facial plethora, proximal muscle weakness, abnormal fat distribution, and easy bruising. He has another type of pituitary adenoma that is much more common and produces other distinct symptoms.
questions.hint: The intrasellar mass seen on this patient's MRI scan is likely a pituitary adenoma that is causing his headaches and bitemporal hemianopia. The most common form of pituitary adenomas is a prolactinoma. What are the potential consequences of this tumor in men?

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after he was hit by a car that he did not see coming. He reports that he has had recurrent headaches and trouble seeing objects in his peripheral vision for several years. Physical examination shows tenderness and swelling of the left arm, left thigh, and right leg. He has minimal facial and body hair. X-rays show decreased cortical thickness, loss of bony trabeculae, and fractures of the left humerus, left femur, and right tibia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has decreased bone density (osteoporosis) as a result of hyperprolactinemia from a prolactinoma, the most common variant (∼ 40%) of pituitary adenoma. This mass can compress the optic chiasm, which results in a loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia). Hyperprolactinemia suppresses pulsatile GnRH release, which leads to decreased sex hormone production (hypogonadism). Testosterone and estrogen are both normally involved in the prevention of bone breakdown and the stimulation of bone formation via activation of osteoblasts and inhibition of osteoclasts. In addition to osteoporosis, other manifestations of hyperprolactinemia include decreased facial and body hair (as seen in this patient), decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, and gynecomastia.

Key learning point: Hyperprolactinemia from a pituitary adenoma can cause bitemporal hemianopsia, osteoporosis due to hypogonadism, and decreased facial and body hair.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism can cause decreased bone density (osteoporosis) as a result of cortisol-mediated inhibition of osteoblast function and enhancement of bone resorption. Increased serum cortisol concentrations can be caused by Cushing disease. Though some patients with Cushing disease have a pituitary macroadenoma that can compress the optic chiasm and cause loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia), most patients have microadenomas that are unlikely to cause a mass effect. In addition, hypercortisolism does not cause decreased facial and body hair. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical features of hypercortisolism, including proximal muscle weakness, central obesity, moon facies, easily bruisable skin, and striae.

C) INCORRECT:

Secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause decreased bone density (osteoporosis) as a result of hypocalcemia. However, this condition does not cause loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia) or decreased facial and body hair. Patients with MEN 1 syndrome can develop primary hyperparathyroidism, which can rarely manifest with bone pain and resorption (osteitis fibrosa cystica) leading to hypercalcemia, and pituitary adenomas. Although this patient presents with features of a pituitary adenoma, hyperparathyroidism alone is not the most likely etiology for this patient's constellation of features.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism results in increased bone resorption and decreased bone density (osteoporosis). Additional manifestations of this condition include hair thinning and visual disturbances. However, the visual disturbances typically seen in patients with hyperthyroidism are diplopia and blurry vision, not loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia). Moreover, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of hyperthyroidism, such as heat intolerance, palpitations, weight loss, increased bowel movements, anxiety, tremor, and lid lag.

E) INCORRECT:

Typical manifestations of primary hyperaldosteronism include hypertension and features of hypokalemia (e.g., headaches, fatigue, muscle weakness). This condition does not cause decreased bone density (osteoporosis), loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia), or decreased facial and body hair.
questions.hint: This patient has a sellar mass that is compressing the optic chiasm, which results in a loss of peripheral vision (bitemporal hemianopsia). The mass is producing a hormone that, in excess, results in decreased bone density (osteoporosis) and decreased facial and body hair.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the gynecology office because of a 4-month history of irregular menstrual cycles. Menses occur at irregular 15 to 45-day intervals and last 1–2 days with minimal flow. She also reports a milk-like discharge from her nipples for 3 months, accompanied by fatigue and muscle and joint pain. She has recently gained 2.5 kg (5.5 lb) of weight. She has hypothyroidism but has not been taking levothyroxine for 6 months. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows vaginal atrophy. Visual field and skin examination are normal. Serum studies show:


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
16.3 μU/mL


Cortisol (8 AM)
18 μg/dL (N = 5–23 μg/dL)


Prolactin
88 ng/mL


An x-ray of the chest and ultrasound of the pelvis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the nipple discharge in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with thyrotropic pituitary adenomas have increased levels of TSH and clinical features of hyperthyroidism (secondary to increased TSH) such as weight loss, heat intolerance, diarrhea, and/or tachycardia. Large thyrotropic adenomas (> 10 mm) can present with features of hyperprolactinemia because they compress the infundibular stalk and result in an interruption of the tonic inhibitory effect of hypothalamic dopamine on the secretion of prolactin (disconnection hyperprolactinemia). However, since this patient is hypothyroid, thyrotropic pituitary adenoma is an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ectopic prolactin production is a paraneoplastic syndrome that occurs in certain tumors such as lung and/or renal cell carcinoma. However, this patient does not have any clinical features suggesting malignancy. Also, ectopic prolactin production is extremely rare when compared with other forms of paraneoplastic hormone secretion (e.g., ectopic ACTH production).

C) INCORRECT:

Cushing disease could present with symptoms of hypercortisolism such as muscle pain and menstrual irregularities. However, the normal levels of early morning cortisol and the absence of hypertension and hyperglycemia make Cushing disease an unlikely diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Increased TSH in a hypothyroid patient (e.g., fatigue, recent weight gain, and myalgia) who has not been taking their levothyroxine medication suggests primary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism, decreased T3 and T4 levels stimulate the secretion of thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) by the hypothalamus, which in turn increases TSH release by the anterior pituitary. In addition to increasing TSH production, excessive TRH also stimulates the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary to release prolactin, thus resulting in a state of hyperprolactinemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Prolactinomas are the most common cause of hyperprolactinemia. However, prolactin levels in a patient with a prolactinoma are usually > 200 ng/mL. A prolactin level < 100 ng/mL in this patient suggests a different cause for hyperprolactinemia. Additionally, most secretory pituitary adenomas do not secrete multiple pituitary hormones, and prolactinomas that secrete TSH are extremely rare. Increased TSH levels suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: Galactorrhea and irregular menstrual cycles are suggestive of hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with 7 months of increasingly irregular menstrual cycles and occasional milky discharge from both breasts. She denies medication use or significant medical history. Gentle compression of either breast yields a few drops of white fluid. She has mild headaches but no visual disturbances.
Which investigation is most likely to confirm the suspected underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms of irregular menstrual cycles and galactorrhea suggest hyperprolactinemia. This condition occurs when elevated prolactin levels disrupt gonadotropin-releasing hormone secretion, leading to ovulatory dysfunction and menstrual irregularities. Additionally, high prolactin levels directly stimulate the mammary glands, causing milky discharge. Measuring serum prolactin is crucial to confirm this endocrine imbalance. If elevated, further evaluation for a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma may be warranted. This test directly quantifies the hormone responsible for the patient's symptoms, providing a biochemical basis for her clinical presentation.

Key learning point: In a patient with irregular menstrual cycles and galactorrhea, serum prolactin measurement is the most helpful investigation to confirm hyperprolactinemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) primarily assess ovarian function and are useful in diagnosing primary ovarian failure or menopause. In hyperprolactinemia, elevated prolactin suppresses gonadotropin-releasing hormone, leading to low FSH and LH levels. These measurements do not confirm a prolactin-secreting disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound evaluates pelvic structures like the uterus and ovaries. While menstrual irregularities might suggest gynecological issues, the presence of galactorrhea and headaches indicates an endocrine disturbance, likely hyperprolactinemia. Imaging of the pituitary, not the pelvis, is needed to assess for a pituitary lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hypothyroidism can cause mild hyperprolactinemia due to elevated thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH). However, the absence of symptoms like weight gain, cold intolerance, and constipation makes thyroid dysfunction unlikely. The patient's symptoms more strongly indicate a pituitary-related cause. Serum TSH evaluates thyroid function but does not confirm a pituitary abnormality.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with reduced libido for several months, intermittent galactorrhea, and amenorrhea for the past six months. She denies headaches, vision changes, recent weight changes, new stressors, and use of medications, including herbal supplements. Physical examination, including optic fundus evaluation, is normal (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Prolactin
2500 pmol/L
< 870 pmol/L


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
3.0 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Human chorionic gonadotropin
0.3 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
5 IU/L
5-20 IU/L


Luteinizing hormone
5 U/L
5 - 22 U/L


Estradiol
70 pmol/L
70 - 530 pmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) measurement screens for growth hormone excess, such as in acromegaly. The patient lacks clinical features of growth hormone excess, and her symptoms and elevated prolactin levels suggest hyperprolactinemia, likely due to a prolactin-secreting adenoma. IGF-1 measurement is not relevant in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, treats prolactinomas by reducing prolactin levels. However, initiating therapy without imaging confirmation of a prolactinoma may obscure the diagnosis and lead to inappropriate management. Imaging, typically with MRI, is necessary to confirm the presence of a pituitary adenoma before starting treatment.

C) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits symptoms of hyperprolactinemia, including reduced libido, galactorrhea, and amenorrhea, with a significantly elevated serum prolactin level. Normal thyroid-stimulating hormone levels exclude hypothyroidism as a cause. These findings suggest a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma (prolactinoma). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the sella turcica is the most appropriate next step to evaluate the pituitary gland for adenomas. MRI provides detailed information on the size and location of the adenoma, which is crucial for management, including potential treatment with dopamine agonists if a prolactinoma is confirmed.

Key learning point: In cases of hyperprolactinemia with symptoms of hypogonadism, a brain MRI is the most useful investigation to evaluate for a pituitary adenoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound evaluates uterine or ovarian pathology but is not indicated here. The patient's symptoms and elevated prolactin levels suggest a central endocrine issue, likely a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. Imaging of the sellar region is more appropriate to assess for adenomas.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of increasingly irregular menstrual cycles and new-onset milky discharge from her breasts. She has no significant past medical history and denies medications, visual changes, headaches, changes in libido, or recent weight fluctuations. Physical examination reveals fine, milky discharge from both nipples (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Human chorionic gonadotropin
0.3 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL


Prolactin
2000 pmol/L
< 870 pmol/L


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.0 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Follicle-stimulating hormone
10 IU/L
5-20 IU/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:
